review.title: SQUINKY! A Corpus of Sentence-level Formality, Informativeness, and Implicature
review.abstract: We introduce a corpus of 7,032 sentences rated by human annotators for formality, informativeness, and implicature on a 1-7 scale. The corpus was annotated using Amazon Mechanical Turk. Reliability in the obtained judgments was examined by comparing mean ratings across two MTurk experiments, and correlation with pilot annotations (on sentence formality) conducted in a more controlled setting. Despite the subjectivity and inherent difficulty of the annotation task, correlations between mean ratings were quite encouraging, especially on formality and informativeness. We further explored correlation between the three linguistic variables, genre-wise variation of ratings and correlations within genres, compatibility with automatic stylistic scoring, and sentential make-up of a document in terms of style. To date, our corpus is the largest sentence-level annotated corpus released for formality, informativeness, and implicature.

sections.text: The reliability of the assessments obtained was examined by comparing average scores in two MTurk experiments and correlation with pilot comments (on sentence formality) conducted in a more controlled setting. Despite the subjectivity and inherent difficulty of the annotation task, correlations between mean scores were quite encouraging, especially in terms of formality and informativity. We also investigated correlations between the three linguistic variables, generic variation of ratings and correlations within genres, compatibility with automatic stylistic assessments, and the stylistic composition of a document. To date, our corpus is the largest sentence-level corpus published in terms of formality, informativeness, and implication.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In our first experiment, we looked at how formality, implication and informativity at the sentence level vary across three different online genres - news, blogs and forums (Section 4.1); in the second experiment, we looked at the correlation between these three variables and the correlation with stylistic scores (Section 4.2); and finally, in Section 4.3, we looked at how documents differ - on average - in terms of sentence formality, informativity and implication.

sections.heading: 4.3 Sentential Make-up of Documents
sections.text: In our last experiment, we examined how the sentences in a document differ in terms of formality, implication and informativeness - starting with the first sentences, then the middle and finally the last. We divided the sentences into ten consecutive containers (deciles) based on their position in the document and measured the mean formality, informativeness and implication per decile. The results - averaged across all documents of a particular genre (blog, forums, news as a whole) - are presented in Figure 2. Figure 2 also shows the default errors for each decile.Note from Figure 2: News sentences are the most formal and informative, followed by blog sentences, followed by forum sentences. In terms of formality and information trends, news sentences begin with a high formality and informativeness, then gradually decrease in both - perhaps reflecting the fact that in journalistic writing at first few sentences contain the most information (to attract readers "attention), and the information content thereafter greatly decreases.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced a data set of 7,032 sentences that were evaluated for formality, informativeness, and implication on a scale of 1-7 by human commentators on Amazon Mechanical Turk. To our knowledge, this is the first major annotation effort that combines all three pragmatic variables at the sentence level. We measured the reliability of our annotations by conducting two independent annotation rounds on MTurk and verifying the correlation between the averages between the two rounds. We further investigated the correlation of our annotations with pilot sentence formality annotations conducted in a more controlled setting (Lahiri and Lu, 2011). It was observed that while formality and informativeness can be reliably annotated on a scale of 1-7, implications represent a much more difficult challenge. We analyzed the distribution of formality, informativeness, and implication in three genres (news, blogs, and forums), and found the overall relationship between the documents to be significant - as well as the differences in relation to the human documents.

metadata.abstractText: We introduce a corpus of 7,032 sentences1 rated by human annotators for formality, informativeness, and implicature on a 1-7 scale. The corpus was annotated using Amazon Mechanical Turk.2 Reliability in the obtained judgments was examined by comparing mean ratings across two MTurk experiments, and correlation with pilot annotations (on sentence formality) conducted in a more controlled setting. Despite the subjectivity and inherent difficulty of the annotation task, correlations between mean ratings were quite encouraging, especially on formality and informativeness. We further explored correlation between the three linguistic variables, genre-wise variation of ratings and correlations within genres, compatibility with automatic stylistic scoring, and sentential make-up of a document in terms of style. To date, our corpus is the largest sentence-level annotated corpus released for formality, informativeness, and implicature.
